parameters: Eugh... who is it now... I swear if it’s another spam call.
<WordWrap>Wha? Why is he calling? Could have sworn our session was next month.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>HOLY SHI... You answered! Are you okay?! This is the tenth time I’ve called this week, I was about to send the police to check in on you.

<WordWrap>What? I’m doing fine. Don’t send the cops, please. I’ve... lost track of time I suppose, I think my phone was on silent. I’m just waiting on the couch right now. Wasn’t our next meeting in a month?
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Oh thank goodness. Look I know it must be hard for you right now but I’m here to talk and...

<WordWrap>Hmm? Oh, for my wife to come back home. They said they were only heading out for a bit and should be back soon. We were gonna watch this show together, she’s been hounding me about it for weeks.

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>I see... Hey, it’s been a while since our last in-person talk. If possible, do you mind coming down to the office today? You can voice any concerns or just talk as long as you want. I can clear as much time as you need.
<WordWrap>That’s uhh real generous of you Doctor but sorry. Like I said, I need to wait for my wife. She’ll be back any minute now.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Alright, alright that’s fine... Hey, by chance, have you ever heard of the five stages of grief?
<WordWrap>Uhh I think so? Anger... bargaining?... depression... acceptance, and what was the other one?

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Denial... It’s the first stage of grief. It’s when something tragic happens to us and our brains, in order to protect us and process the information, pretend that nothing is wrong until it is ready.
<WordWrap>Ok? Can you get to the point Doctor?

\n<Therapist><WordWrap> *sigh* Do me a favour? Have a look around your house for items that are meaningful to both of you, think of it as homework for our next session. Perhaps start in your \c[4]Bedroom.\
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Oh and I’ll probably be calling again every so often to check up on you. Ok, I’ll leave you to it.
<WordWrap>That was... strange. Well since I’m waiting anyway, I might as well get a headstart on this “homework”.
<WordWrap>Hey bud\., just checking in to see how you are feeling today.
<WordWrap>Remember, \.if you think you can’t make any more progress, or you just need a day to \c[4]RESET\c[0] then feel free to stop and try again tomorrow by heading to bed.
<WordWrap>Destroying the \c[1]boulders\c[0] may be the only option...
\n<Therapist><WordWrap> Hey bud! Listen, I’ve got some general tips for you to think about as you complete the homework I gave you earlier.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>The mind is a tricky thing. Sometimes it tries to help us by hiding away certain facts that hurt us.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>You can think of the mind as being partially made up of \c[4]movable blocks, locked doors\c[0] and \c[4]switches\c[0].

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>The blocks clutter your mind and prevent you from moving forward. Often, these can be \c[4]pushed\c[0] out of the way or made beneficial by moving them in the right spot to activate a \c[4]switch\c[0].

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>\c[4]Switches\c[0] once activated, can open \c[4]doors\c[0] that have previously blocked our path. It just takes some thinking or \c[4]moving Blocks\c[0] to find and activate them.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>\c[4]\c[0]Locked Doors are more rigid barriers. These can be unlocked through \c[4]switches\c[0].
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Remember, if you get stuck you can always take a break, go to \c[4]bed\c[0], \c[4]reset\c[0] your mind, and try again tomorrow.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Anyway, some food for thought. I hope some of what I said can help you, I’ll call back every so often to check-in.
<WordWrap>I love this portrait of her. Got it done in renaissance style.
<WordWrap>Hmm? What is that hanging on this?
<WordWrap>What the fuck? What kind of sick joke is this? Why is my wife’s name and face on this? She isn’t dead, she just...She just...
ARGH! My damn head hurts, what the hell?
<WordWrap>That was just two weeks ago?! This can’t be real. It’s not real. This is some kind of messed up joke they’re pulling on me
<WordWrap>Soon she’ll walk in, I’ll show her this bad joke and we’ll laugh about it.
<WordWrap>She’ll be back anytime now. But... When did she leave again? I can’t remember... Why can’t I remember?
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Hey, how’s the homework I’ve assigned you going?
She really is gone isn’t she?
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Yeah... Yeah, I’m afraid so. Do you remember what happened now?
<WordWrap>...She died on her way to the grocery store in a car crash. A drunk driver hit her directly on her driver’s side and she died instantly...
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Right... Did you want to come to the office to talk about it?
<WordWrap>No... No, I don’t really want to leave today. I think I need to lay down.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Alright, get some rest and we can try to tackle things tomorrow.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Just calling to check in. How are you feeling today?

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Ok, ok, I will. Just let me know if you want to talk later. Also, make sure you’re taking care of yourself. Make yourself some food, clean the house, try to keep busy. I know after losing your-
<WordWrap>Shut up. Don’t pretend to be my friend. The only one who really cared was my wife and now she’s gone. So leave me the hell alone and collect your pathetic cheque from my company insurance.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>... Alright. I’ll give you some time and call back later.
<WordWrap>*sigh* I shouldn’t have said all that...This house is a goddamn disaster. But that’s fine, I hate this place anyway. Everything I look at is a reminder...
<WordWrap>The therapist was right on one thing. I am hungry. I should go to the kitchen and see what’s survived.
<WordWrap>Ow! God damn oil. Where the hell did I put the pan cover?
<WordWrap>OW ARGHH FFFU- I HATE THIS. I HATE THIS HOUSE, I HATE THAT SHE LEFT ME ALONE LIKE THIS. ARGHHH!!
<WordWrap>I’d give anything to have her here…..If only I’d gone to the store instead of her that day, I’d gladly give my life for her’s.
Hi...I still can’t get my mind off what happened.
<WordWrap>I keep going back and forth thinking “what if I had done something to stop her? Why didn’t I go instead? Why didn’t I go with her at least?”
\n<Therapist>These kinds of questions are all perfectly natural after losing a loved one.

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Look, I know you haven’t been out of the house since the funeral. You might feel more comfortable getting out for a bit. Would you like to come down to the office where we could talk?
<WordWrap>No...no I don’t think I feel up for leaving. I just don’t have the energy.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>That’s fine. Go at your own pace.

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Listen, to take your mind off of things for a bit, try immersing yourself in one of your hobbies. You play some instruments and have a music room right? Expressing yourself with music might help you.
<WordWrap>We did have a track we were working on. Maybe if I can just complete it I’ll feel better.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Alright, let me know how it goes. I’ll check in later okay?

<WordWrap>My guitar. We made several disks since we weren’t sure how to combine all this. The first one she made is \c[3]green\c[0], the second is \c[6]yellow\c[0], and the last one is \c[4]blue\c[0].
<WordWrap> I have a feeling if I can just piece it all together the way she wanted it to be, then I might feel happy, just for a moment. Please let me be happy doing this.
<WordWrap>This is it! This is what she wanted!
<WordWrap>But somethings wrong... I don’t feel any better... This was supposed to make me happy, for just a minute I was supposed to forget.
<WordWrap>*sniff* why didn’t it work? It was supposed to work. I don’t know what else to do...
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Hello? Hey, I know today must be a rough day for you, I’m just making sure you’re okay.
<WordWrap>We were going to go on another trip but this time it was my turn to plan it.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>I know... You both sounded very excited about it before.
<WordWrap>I don’t know what to do. I don’t feel good and I don’t know how to fix it. I don’t know if it can be fixed.

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Remember, you still have friends, family and me who are willing to help you through this even as we all grieve. You don’t have to do it alone. I’m going to clear up my entire night so you and I can have a discussion. To really work through this.
<WordWrap>We’ve already talked and it didn’t help.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>I would like to think you are at the point where you might really benefit from it now.

\n<Therapist><WordWrap>I’m going to call back later. Oh. Also, it’s gotten very cold outside and I know that house is not the best for insulation. Maybe try finding your winter stuff to keep you warm. You said before all of it was in the basement right?
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Anyway I’ll call you back tonight. Take care.
<WordWrap>this is where we put all of our winter gear. This is her toque, gloves, that scarf I bought her for Christmas. All the things she would have worn on our trip for her birthday.
<WordWrap>It’s not fair for her or me that she’s gone. How am I supposed to keep going? This whole year I’ve been a wreck and I can’t see myself getting better.
<WordWrap>I don’t know what to do. I don’t know what to do.
I can't do this anymore. It's too hard.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Hey bud, how are you doing? I’m cleared for the night and now we can talk as much as you want.
Yeah, I think I would like that.
I think I'm feeling a little bit better.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>That’s good to hear! Do you think you’re ready to leave the house and come meet me at the office like we talked about?
<WordWrap>Yeah I’ve just been making sure I look okay when I leave the house.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Great! I can’t wait to see you here. It’s been way too long.
<WordWrap>If you don’t mind, I might stop by the graveyard with some friends before meeting you. Going back there is long overdue.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Are you sure you’ll be fine doing that?

<WordWrap>I’m not sure. It still hurts bad but I’ve spent too long with my life on hold. She would hate how I’ve been living. “Where is the adventure” she would probably think. Anyway, my friends will help me if I need it and I’ll talk about it with you when I come for the appointment.
I think I'll need the conversation.
\n<Therapist><WordWrap>Alright. Just as long as you’re fine with it.
<WordWrap>Ok. I think I’m ready to head out. I’ll see you soon.
<WordWrap>Oh, and, thank you for helping me this past year.
